Note: This document is for internal use only.

title: Data & Metadata
text:
Bioinformatics tools are very strict about filenames, sample IDs, and metadata.
Even one wrong character can:

break pipelines
mismatch samples
cause failed downstream analyses (DESeq2, Seurat)
make reproducibility impossible

So, we require standardized naming.

title: Basic Unix Commands
text:
Most bioinformatics tools run in a terminal, not a graphical program.
Unix commands let you:

move around folders
list and inspect files
run analysis programs

title: Basic Unix Commands
text:
Navigation (Where am I?)
Before you can analyze data, you must know how to move around the folders (directories).

pwd (Print Working Directory): Shows your current location.
ls (List): Shows files in the current folder.
cd folder/ (Change Directory): Move into a folder.
cd ..: Move one level up.
cd ~: Go to your home directory.
mkdir name (Make Directory): Create a new folder.

title: Basic Unix Commands
text:
Inspecting Files
Never open a ~10GB FASTQ file in a text editor like Word or Notepad. It will crash. Use these instead:

head -n 20 file.txt: See the first 20 lines.
tail -n 20 file.txt: See the last 20 lines (useful for checking if a log file finished correctly).

title: Basic Unix Commands
text:
Copy and move files

cp file folder/: Copy file from the first argument (source) to the last (destination).
mv file folder/: Move file from the first argument (source) to the last (destination).
rm file: Remove file. Caution: There is no ‚ÄúTrash Can‚Äù, Removed files are gone.

title: Basic Unix Commands
text:
Working with Compressed Data
Bioinformatics data is almost always compressed (.gz) to save space.

zcat name.fastq.gz | head: View the top of a compressed fastq file.
gzip file: Compresses a file and adds a .gz extension.
gunzip file.gz: Decompresses the file.

title: Basic Unix Commands
text:
Counting and Searching

wc -l file.txt: count lines.
grep "searchterm" file.txt: find lines containing a word.
grep -c "^@" file.fastq: Count how many sequence headers (starting with @) are in a file.

title: Welcome
text:
Getting Started
The goal of this guide is to bridge the gap between wet-lab experiments and dry-lab results.
You will learn:

how to prepare your data correctly
how to use basic Unix commands
how to run analyses in the computational infrastructure of INAB

title: Data & Metadata
text:
üìÑ Project Documentation (The README file)
Standardized names are only useful if we know the context of the project. To prevent the loss of critical project details (who did what a year later), every project folder MUST contain a README file.

Recommended Template
Create a file named README.txt in your main project folder and use this structure:
Project: Short Title
Project owner: Name
Bioinformatician: Name
Date Started: YYYY-MM-DD
Status: In Progress / Completed / Archived
Experimental Details: A brief description with the contex of the project (e.g.¬†Comparisons, Groups)

title: FastQC Analysis
text:
FastQC is the first step in any NGS pipeline. It provides a modular set of analyses which help you spot potential problems in your sequencing data (e.g., adapter contamination, low-quality bases).



Log in to the server: Open your terminal and connect to the analysis node: ssh username@160.40.71.4
Locate your data: Identify where your NGS results (.fastq.gz files) are located.
Example path: /mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research/2025_05_21_ERIC_study
Move to the working directory: We perform our analyses in the precmed volume: bash     cd /work/precmed/varCall/
Create an output directory: Always keep your results organized in a dated folder. bash     mkdir run-2025-05-22-fastqc
Run FastQC: Use the wildcard *.fastq.gz to process all samples at once. Ensure you point the -o flag to your newly created directory. bash     fastqc /mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research/2025_05_21_ERIC_study/*.fastq.gz -o run-2025-05-22-fastqc/

title: FastQC Analysis
text:
üìä Interpreting the Results
Once the run finishes, FastQC will generate an .html report for every file. Open these in a web browser to check the following key modules:

‚úÖ Per base sequence quality: Most bases should be in the ‚Äúgreen‚Äù zone (> Q30). If the quality drops significantly at the end of the reads, you may need to perform trimming.
‚úÖ Adapter Content: If this module fails, it means Illumina adapter sequences were detected. You must remove these before alignment.
‚úÖ Sequence Duplication Levels: High duplication can indicate PCR over-amplification or low library complexity.


[!TIP] MultiQC: If you have dozens of samples, looking at individual reports is slow. Use MultiQC to aggregate all FastQC reports into a single, easy-to-read summary page.

title: BCL Convert
text:
Log in to the appropriate server:
o 160.40.71.4
Identify where your NGS results (.bcl files and SampleSheet) are located:
o e.g., /mnt/new_home/illumina/nextseq2000/240412_VH00795_60_AAFLFTVM5
Create your SampleSheet.csv:
o Generally, a SampleSheet must include two sections: (1) the Settings Section and (2) the Data Section
o In the Data Section you can add a column named Sample_Project containing the name of the respective project for each sample. Sample_Project Optional can only contain alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores. Duplicate data strings with different cases (e.g., sampleProject and SampleProject) are not allowed. If these are used, analysis fails.
Move to your working folder:
o In case there are only samples from your lab run:
cd /mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research/
o In case there are samples from multiple labs run:
cd /mnt/new_home/illumina_common_fastq
Upload your SampleSheet.csv to your working folder:
o Any SFTP program (e.g., Bitvise SSH Client) can be used to transfer SampleSheet.csv. Just drag & drop the file from the left to the right window.
Define a distinctive name for the folder that will contain the bcl-convert results (e.g., 2025_05_20_ERIC_study) and use it as input after the ‚Äìoutput-directory argument (check the command below)
Now you can execute bcl-convert (version 00.000.000.3.10.12), based on the following command:
nohup bcl-convert \
--bcl-input-directory /mnt/new_home/illumina/nextseq2000/240412_VH00795_60_AAFLFTVM5 \
--output-directory 2025_05_20_ERIC_study \
--sample-sheet SampleSheet.csv \
--no-lane-splitting true \
--bcl-sampleproject-subdirectories \
-‚Äìforce > ./2025_05_20_ERIC_study.log 2>&1 &
After the command for bcl-convert has run successfully, move your SampleSheet.csv to the output folder:
mv SampleSheet.csv 2025_05_20_ERIC_study
Files older than 2 weeks will be automatically deleted from shared folders!
For this reason, if we have run the analysis in a shared folder such as /mnt/new_home/illumina_common_fastq, we should transfer the final files to our own subfolder, which will be located under our research group‚Äôs folder.
rsync -r \
/mnt/new_home/illumina_common_fastq/2025_05_20_ERIC_study \
/mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research

title: bases2fastq
text:
Log in to the appropriate server:
o 160.40.71.4
Identify where your NGS results (.bcl files and SampleSheet) are located:
o e.g., /mnt/new_home/element/AV240301/20250131_AV240301_SARSDIAGNOSIS
Activate conda environment with dependencies for bases2fastq:
source activate /apps/miniconda3/envs/bases2fastq_dependencies
Create your RunManifest.csv:
o Information for preparing the RunManifest file can be found here.
o You can add a column named Project containing the name of the respective project for each sample.
o In the Data Section you can add a column named Project containing the name of the respective project for each sample.
Project can only contain alphanumeric characters, dashes, and underscores.
Move to your working folder:
o In case there are only samples from your lab run:
cd /mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research/

2025_05_21_ERIC_study/ > ./2025_05_21_ERIC_study.log 2>&1 &
After the command for bases2fastq has run successfully, move your RunManifest.csv to the output folder:

2025_05_21_ERIC_study \

title: RNAseq analysis
text:
Log in to the appropriate server:
o 160.40.71.4
Identify where your NGS results (.fastq files) are located:
o e.g., /mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research/2025_05_21_ERIC_study
Move to the your working directory:
cd /work/folder_of_each_user
Create a new analysis directory:
mkdir RNAseq_analysis_2025_05_21
Move to the your new analysis directory:
cd /work/RNAseq_analysis_2025_05_21
Download script to your analysis directory
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/natanast/RNAseq_analysis/main/bash/star.sh
wget https://raw.githubusercontent.com/natanast/RNAseq_analysis/main/bash/runSTAR.sh 
Create a SampleList (you have to update with the right path to your fastq files), for example:
ls -la /mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research/RNAseq_2025_05_21 | awk '{print $9}' | awk -F "_R" '{print $1}' | sort | uniq > SampleList
Remove samples that should not be analyzed:
nano SampleList
In order to edit the SampleList use the following:
o Delete button: Removes one letter
o Ctrl + k: Removes a whole row
o Ctrl + o and Enter: Saves the modified SampleList
o Ctrl + x: Exits and returns to the terminal
Run the analysis (you have to update with the right path):
nohup bash runSTAR.sh \
/mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research/RNAseq_2025_05_21 \
SampleList \
/mnt/new_home/bio_tmp/HSapRefData/hg38/gencode/star \
/mnt/new_home/bio_tmp/HSapRefData/hg38/gencode/gencode.v47.primary_assembly.basic.annotation.gtf \
16 \
&
After the analysis is completed, move your folder from /work to /mnt/new_home
cd ..
rsync -r \
RNAseq_analysis_2025_05_21 \
/mnt/new_home/stamatopoulos_research

title: ENA Data Deposit
text:
Prerequisites (What do I need?)
Before you start the submission process, ensure you have the following components ready.

Webin Account: You need a submission account registered at ENA.
FASTQ Files: Your raw sequencing data, compressed (.fastq.gz).
FTP Client: A tool like FileZilla is required to transfer your files via FTP.

title: ENA Data Deposit
text:
Data Integrity (MD5 Checksum)
When you upload large sequencing files, it is possible for the data to get corrupted during the transfer. To prevent this, we use MD5 checksums.
Think of an MD5 checksum as a ‚Äúdigital fingerprint‚Äù for your file.

md5 checksum Generation for your fastq
cd /path/to/your/desirable/directory
md5sum /mnt/new_home/illumina/nextseq2000/name/of/the/run/V*fastq* | awk '{print $2, $1}' | paste - - > filenames_and_checksums_date.txt

title: ENA Data Deposit
text:
FTP Client to ENA
Establish connection. Drag ‚Äòn‚Äô Drop fastq files.

title: ENA Data Deposit
text:
Webin Submission Portal
https://www.ebi.ac.uk/ena/submit/webin/login
Use credentials to login. Navigate to tabs ‚ÄúSubmit Reads‚Äù and ‚ÄúRegister Samples‚Äù

title: ENA Data Deposit
text:
The Manifest File
The first component of a successful submission is the Manifest file. This text file tells ENA exactly what your data is. It is submitted via the ‚ÄúSubmit Reads‚Äù option. Create a file named manifest.tsv or download the spreadsheet template from Webin Submission Portal. For submitting paired reads using fastq files it is required to use the specific format.
Example manifest.tsv:
FileType fastq Read submission file type sample study instrument_model library_name library_source library_selection library_strategy library_layout forward_file_name forward_file_md5 reverse_file_name reverse_file_md5

title: ENA Data Deposit
text:
The Metadata File
The second component of a successful submission is the Metadata file. This tab delimited file contains all the information about the submitted samples. It is submitted via the ‚ÄúRegister Samples‚Äù option. Create a file named metadata.tsv or download a spreadsheet template from Webin Submission Portal alike Manifest. Note that the template varies depending on the specific checklist (e.g., GSC MIxS soil, Virus pathogen reporting standard) that matches your sample type. For submitting SARS-CoV-2, the respective checklist is ERC000033 (ENA virus pathogen reporting standard checklist)
Example metadata.tsv:
Checklist ERC000033 ENA virus pathogen reporting standard checklist tax_id scientific_name sample_alias sample_title sample_description collection date geographic location (country and/or sea) host common name host subject id host health state host sex host scientific name collector name collecting institution isolate common name

text:

Establish FTP connection with ENA.
Upload the fastq files (Drag‚Äôn‚ÄôDrop)
Login to Webin Submission Portal
Upload manifest.tsv through ‚ÄúSubmit Reads‚Äù
Upload metadata.tsv through ‚ÄúRegister Samples‚Äù
Win

title: ERGO-ii analysis
text:
Steps

Creating ERGO-II input files

Open RStudio
Set up your working directory ‚Äì find the folder where your data are located and choose ‚ÄúSet as Working Directory‚Äù



Download the necessary R scripts from here: ERGO-helpers/R at main ¬∑ BiodataAnalysisGroup/ERGO-helpers and place them into your working directory.
Open the 01.build_ergo_inputs.R and update it with the right path of the data to run first (lines 14 + 15, remove the others if necessary).
Provide an output folder name of preference (line 17)
Run the script
When complete a folder will be created with the following structure:
my_output_folder/
‚îú‚îÄ ergo-ii-input_sample1.csv
‚îú‚îÄ ergo-ii-input_sample2.csv
‚îú‚îÄ ...



Steps to run ERGO:

Log in to the appropriate server:
o 160.40.71.4
Move to the your working directory:
cd /work/folder_of_each_user
Create a new analysis directory:
mkdir ergo-ii_2026-01-07
Move to the your new analysis directory:
cd /work/ergo-ii_2026-01-07
Download script to your analysis directory
git clone https://github.com/BiodataAnalysisGroup/ERGO-helpers.git
Move to the your new analysis directory:
cd ERGO-helpers/ERGO-II
Create a folder named data and upload your data there:
mkdir data
Create a sample list:
ls -la data/ | awk '{print $9}' | awk -F "_" '{print $2}' | awk -F "." '{print $1}' | sort | uniq > SampleList
Remove samples that should not be analyzed:
nano SampleList
In order to edit the SampleList use the following:
o Delete button: Removes one letter
o Ctrl + k: Removes a whole row
o Ctrl + o and Enter: Saves the modified SampleList
o Ctrl + x: Exits and returns to the terminal
Run the analysis (you have to update with the right path):
bash runERGO-II.sh > run.sh
nohup bash run.sh &
When complete score files will be created inside the folder you have uploaded.



Filtering ERGO-II results

Go back to your working directory (RStudio).
Set it as your Working Directory (same steps as before).
Create a new folder (e.g.¬†ergo-ii_scores) and download the resulted scores files from the server.
Open the 02.filter_ergo_scores.R and update it with the right path of the data to run first (lines 9 + 10, remove the others if necessary).
Provide an output folder name of preference (line 12).
Run the script.
